awd_titl_txt: OIDA Annual Forum 2010. To Be Held November 16-17, 2010 in Arlington, VA.
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal seeks funds to support the 2010 Annual OIDA Forum on Optoelectronics, to be held in the Waterview Conference Center in Arlington, VA on November 16th and 17th.

Intellectual Merit:
The Forum will assemble high-level  speakers from industry, government and academia who will provide keynote presentations. In addition panel discussions and poster sessions are scheduled, to offer a platform for broad interaction between all the participants and help identify key novel directions in Optoelectronics research, technology and applications.

Broader Impact:
The OIDA forum has been held every second year for the past ten years. It has helped create opportunities for industry and academia to find common interest and generate new collaborations.
In addition to disseminating the advances in the field the Forum fosters participation from students, with a student poster session to broaden the dialog on current graduate research with the audience.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

por.por_cntn:
The Optoelectronics Industry Development Association (OIDA) is a non-profit industry assocation located in Washington, DC.

OIDA held a 1 1/2-day forum on U.S. Competitiveness and the Future of Telecom on November 16-17, 2010, in Arlington, Virginia. The goal of the forum was to bring together industry, government, and academia to address major issues in the telecommunications industry. The forum featured speakers and presentations from carriers, major industry players, and government agencies. The agenda included the following sessions:

U.S. Competitiveness in a Global Economy
Government Agency Perspectives
Telecom Infrastructure and Challenges
The Future of Telecom
National Broadband Plan Roundtable
What's Next: A Panel Discussion

With NSF funding, OIDA solicited academic researchers from around the United States to present posters as the focus and highlight of the evening reception and the next day's morning activities. NSF support helped students offset travel and hotel costs. OIDA allocated time on the agenda for NSF to provide an overview of the photonics research programs sponsored by NSF and for the students to introduce briefly the work that they were exhibiting at the poster session.

The poster session provided students an excellent opportunity to meet high-level management and technical personnel. Industry leaders, on the other hand, had the opportunity to become acquainted with cutting-edge academic research. It also created opportunities for industry and academia to find common interest areas for future collaboration.

Student participation in the OIDA Annual Forum contributed to workforce development in science, engineering, and technology. It also benefits numerous existing photonics programs through the government such as those sponsored by NSF, DoD, NIST, etc. Their participation also helps industry, especially small companies that normally have limited access to academia, to develop collaborative relationships with academic researchers. All companies benefit from access to new applications for photonic devices and systems identified in academic research.

Modified by: Frederic Quan
